subject: RE: [junit] How do I make Unit Testing practical?
msgSnippet: Here are some reasons to unit test: 1) Find the problem before someone else does. 2) The problem is found close to the source (coding) thus the time to solve
messageBody:
Here are some reasons to unit test:
1) Find the problem before someone else does.
2) The problem is found close to the source (coding) thus the time to solve
it is shorter.
3) Refactoring existing code is much easier when a test suite is already
present as one can see what broke.
4) In most cases, you either spend the time unit testing up front, prior to
releasing the software, or you
spend the equivalent time fixing bugs in released software. Unit testing
can be viewed as virtually free.
5) The tests live on long after developers have left the project.

Here are some reasons to use JUnit:
1) It's a true testing framework that can be extended. Why write your own?
2) The tests are easily automatable from a build script since they are
consistently written.
3) There are no external "data" or input files to get lost, as there may be
in main() type tests.
4) There is no output to look through since conditions are asserted in the
code.
5) A test skeleton can be built by some of the IDE's out there today.
6) Since there are no parameters to most JUnit tests there is really no
external documentation necessary.
7) Mention the word JUnit and anyone familiar with it can be up to speed
quickly with any tests written in it.
8) It's idiot proof; it either passes or fails.
9) Most programmers aren't "proud" enough of their tests, or aren't willing
to admit they have very few tests, so no tests are checked into a source
code repository. This is certainly not the case with JUnit.

Brian Peterson
